                    Text: 
                    Psilotsin

4-Hydroxy-N,N-dimethyltryptamine

Molecular Weight

204.27 g/mol

Computed by PubChem 2.2 (PubChem release 2021.10.14)

Dates

Create:

2005-03-25

Modify:

2025-04-19

Description

Psilocin is a tryptamine alkaloid that is N,N-dimethyltryptamine carrying an additional hydroxy substituent at position 4. A hallucinogenic alkaloid isolated in trace amounts from Psilocybe mushrooms (also known as Teonanacatl or "magic mushrooms"). It has a role as a hallucinogen, a serotonergic agonist, a fungal metabolite, a human xenobiotic metabolite and a drug metabolite. It is a tryptamine alkaloid, a tertiary amino compound, a member of hydroxyindoles and a member of phenols. It is functionally related to a N,N-dimethyltryptamine. It is a conjugate base of a psilocinium.


                    Context: 
                    This excerpt provides specific details about Psilotsin, a synonym of psilocin, including its chemical name, molecular weight, and key properties. It summarizes its chemical structure, origin from Psilocybe mushrooms, and pharmacological roles, aligning with the comprehensive chemical and biological data presented throughout the full PubChem document.

                    Text: 
                    Psilocyn is a DEA Schedule I controlled substance. Substances in the DEA Schedule I have no currently accepted medical use in the United States, a lack of accepted safety for use under medical supervision, and a high potential for abuse. It is a Hallucinogenic substances substance.

Psilocin has been reported in Gymnopilus spectabilis, Deconica pseudobullacea, and other organisms with data available.

                    Text: 
                    7.1.1 ClinicalTrials.gov

7.2 DEA Drug and Chemical Information

7.2.1 DEA Controlled Substances

Substance

Psilocyn

DEA Controlled Substances Code Number

7438

Controlled Substances Act Schedule

Schedule I - Substances in the DEA Schedule I have no currently accepted medical use in the United States, a lack of accepted safety for use under medical supervision, and a high potential for abuse.

Class

Hallucinogenic substances

8 Pharmacology and Biochemistry

8.1 MeSH Pharmacological Classification

Hallucinogens

Drugs capable of inducing illusions, hallucinations, delusions, paranoid ideations, and other alterations of mood and thinking. Despite the name, the feature that distinguishes these agents from other classes of drugs is their capacity to induce states of altered perception, thought, and feeling that are not experienced otherwise. (See all compounds classified as Hallucinogens.)

8.2 Metabolism / Metabolites


                    Context: 
                    This chunk provides detailed regulatory and pharmacological classification information for psilocin, including DEA scheduling, controlled substances status, and its categorization as a hallucinogen in medical classification systems. It is essential for understanding legal restrictions and its role within pharmacology and drug safety contexts in the full chemical profile.

metadata.title: Psilocin | C12H16N2O | CID 4980 - PubChem
metadata.description: Psilocin | C12H16N2O | CID 4980 - structure, chemical names, physical and chemical properties, classification, patents, literature, biological activities, safety/hazards/toxicity information, supplier lists, and more.

content:
Drug: Psilocin  | cid: 4980
Source: pubchem | Source description: Psilocin | C12H16N2O | CID 4980 - structure, chemical names, physical and chemical properties, classification, patents, literature, biological activities, safety/hazards/toxicity information, supplier lists, and more.

                    Text: 
                    8.2 Metabolism / Metabolites

Psilocin has known human metabolites that include (2S,3S,4S,5R)-6-[[3-[2-(dimethylamino)ethyl]-1H-indol-4-yl]oxy]-3,4,5-trihydroxyoxane-2-carboxylic acid.

S73 | METXBIODB | Metabolite Reaction Database from BioTransformer | DOI:10.5281/zenodo.4056560

8.3 Transformations

9 Use and Manufacturing

9.1 Uses

Psilocin is a psychedelic (hallucinogenic) mushroom alkaloid. It is found in most psychedelic mushrooms together with its phosphorylated counterpart psilocybin. Psilocin is the pharmacologically active agent in the body after ingestion of psilocybin or psychedelic mushrooms. (L1673)

9.1.1 Use Classification

Pharmaceuticals

S72 | NTUPHTW | Pharmaceutically Active Substances from National Taiwan University | DOI:10.5281/zenodo.3955664

10 Safety and Hazards

10.1 Hazards Identification

10.1.1 GHS Classification

Pictogram(s)

Irritant

Signal

Warning

GHS Hazard Statements

H302 (100%): Harmful if swallowed [Warning Acute toxicity, oral]


                    Context: 
                    This excerpt covers key metabolic, safety, and usage information for psilocin, including its known human metabolites, the active role after ingesting psilocybin, and hazard classification as an irritant and potentially harmful if swallowed. It is essential for understanding psilocin’s biological processing, pharmacological application, and safety profile within the comprehensive chemical profile provided in the full PubChem data record.

                    Text: 
                    10.1.2 Hazard Classes and Categories

Acute Tox. 4 (100%)

10.2 Regulatory Information

DEA Controlled Substances

DEA schedule I controlled substance

21 CFR Sections 1308.11-1308.15 https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-21/chapter-II/part-1308

11 Toxicity

11.1 Toxicological Information

11.1.1 Toxicity Summary

Psilocin acts as a partial agonist at the 5-HT2A serotonin receptor in the brain where it mimics the effects of serotonin (5-HT). It is an 5-HT1A and 5-HT2A/2C agonist. (L1673)

11.1.2 Carcinogen Classification

Carcinogen Classification

No indication of carcinogenicity to humans (not listed by IARC).

11.1.3 Health Effects

Psilocin is neurotoxic and can cause hallucinations. (L1673)

11.1.4 Exposure Routes

Oral, dermal, inhalation, and parenteral (contaminated drugs). (A3101)

11.1.5 Symptoms


                    Context: 
                    This section details the toxicity and regulatory classification of psilocin, including hazard categories, DEA schedule I status, and toxicological information. It highlights psilocin's mechanism as a serotonin receptor agonist, absence of carcinogenicity evidence, neurotoxic potential, exposure routes, and associated symptoms, providing critical safety and legal context within the comprehensive chemical profile.

content:
Drug: Psilocin  | cid: 4980
Source: pubchem | Source description: Psilocin | C12H16N2O | CID 4980 - structure, chemical names, physical and chemical properties, classification, patents, literature, biological activities, safety/hazards/toxicity information, supplier lists, and more.

                    Text: 
                    11.1.3 Health Effects

Psilocin is neurotoxic and can cause hallucinations. (L1673)

11.1.4 Exposure Routes

Oral, dermal, inhalation, and parenteral (contaminated drugs). (A3101)

11.1.5 Symptoms

Psilocin may cause tachycardia, dilated pupils, restlessness or arousal, euphoria, open and closed eye visuals, synesthesia, increased body temperature, headache, sweating and chills, and nausea. (L1673)

11.1.6 Acute Effects
